Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Scholarships Creating Opportunities for Applying Mathematics (S-COAM) project at Indiana University of Pennsylvania establishes supportive connections between Master's students and undergraduates through various cohort activities, while increasing numbers of students pursuing mathematics degrees, improving retention, and enhancing recruitment from regional community colleges. Scholarships support ten students seeking the Master's of Science degree in Applied Mathematics, and 18 undergraduates seeking a major in a mathematical area or minor in mathematics with another science-related major; at least 49 students are supported over three years. Effectiveness is assessed by student surveys and an outside evaluator.

The highlights of S-COAM include the formation of a supportive cohort of students focused on applied mathematics, mentoring and leadership opportunities for participating Master's students and undergraduates, expectations of students doing research or internships and attendance of STEM-related presentations by visiting scholars.

S-COAM expands career options of women, minorities, first-generation, economically disadvantaged, rural, and others by providing support to pursue advanced mathematics coursework and providing workforce-ready graduates trained on industry standard software. S-COAM builds university and student connections in the region through internship and job placement with local businesses as well recruitment visits to and research presentations at local educational institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Scholarships Creating Opportunities for Applying Mathematics (S-COAM) project at Indiana University of Pennsylvania (IUP) has increased the number of students pursuing mathematics degrees through its unique goal of establishing a supportive connection of Master's students with undergraduates through scholarship cohort activities.

Over a period of four years, need-based scholarships supported 27 graduate students from the M.S. in Applied Mathematics and 54 undergraduates seeking a major in a mathematical area or a mathematics minor with another science-related major from biology, chemistry, computer science, geoscience, natural science, or physics. Through this project students participated in monthly cohort meetings, technology workshops, and networking events with graduate students, faculty, industry mentors, and external speakers. These high-impact practices improve retention, persistence and academic performance, enhancing student preparation to begin challenging STEM careers and pursue advanced study. Monthly meetings engaged students in professional development activities, showcased applications of math and science, and provided opportunities to improve critical thinking, communication and presentation skills, and to share internship experiences and research work. Additionally, individual academic performance was carefully monitored and faculty mentoring encouraged students to take more advanced mathematics coursework.

Regional recruiting efforts used faculty and S-COAM scholar representatives to encourage more students to pursue graduate studies via these scholarships. Undergraduate scholarships increased retention and persistence of IUP students and encouraged science students to minor in mathematics. Specific program outcomes include: 

* Direct support for undergraduates including 17 mathematics majors and 37 science majors with a mathematics minor. All undergraduates completed or are continuing in their degree programs. The cohort also had a higher average GPA than their math and science peers.

* Internships or REUs were completed by 26 students, and 13 pursued graduate programs in mathematics, applied mathematics, geoscience, physics, and chemistry.

* Among 27 graduate students from the M.S. in Applied Mathematics program, 16 graduated, 5 continued with the program, 3 left for non-academic reasons, 3 left due to academic performance. Internships were completed by 11 graduate students and 3 pursued Ph.D. programs in mathematical science and pure mathematics.

* Career placements include IBM, NASA, Bayer, Ernst & Young, S&T Bank, University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, and Highmark Insurance and more.

* Out of 81 students, 37 (46%) were female. All female students completed or continued in STEM degree programs, and 8 (30%) of the 27 graduating undergraduate female students pursued advanced degree programs in mathematics, physics, geoscience, climate modeling, mathematics education, MBA, and environmental science.

* Of the 25 graduating with a minor in mathematics, 8 (32%) are pursuing graduate programs; among the 10 undergraduates completing mathematics degrees, 5 (50%) are pursuing graduate programs. 

Intellectual Merits and Broader Impacts include:

* Developing assessment tools for investigating the relationship between student-faculty interaction, associated networking, project ownership, the development of a mathematics professional identity, and student success with persistence to STEM career placement or graduate school.

* Analyzing the impact of programming and opportunities on the cohort and university environment to increase knowledge of best practices in the scholarship of teaching and learning.

* Engaging every cohort member each semester to work on math and science related projects in small teams comprised of a supportive mix of Master’s students and undergraduates. Second-year students also work together to design monthly meeting activities.

* Sharing outcomes of engaging students in research or internships via support for conference travel to present results.

* Enhancing IUP’s scientific computing research environment by regularly offering software workshops and inviting external speakers from national labs, industry, or universities.

* Augmenting students’ ability to pursue science-related degrees with significant mathematical requirements and preparing them to pursue advanced STEM degrees.
